PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

A NOTE OF ACKNOWLEDGEMENT TO THE 1947-1950

BUSINESS OF THE SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because

individuals who are asked to answer it have exactly the same experiences as others.

Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences or others may prove

impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use ex-

planations of answers if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't

hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer

the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada be-

fore 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer

years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should

write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did

Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already

answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at

a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be

willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires

( ) Pioneer health conditions

( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation

( ) Pioneer housing

( ) Pioneer education and churchwork

( ) Pioneer farming experience

Presentation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's

Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our

Province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,

University of Saskatchewan,

Saskatoon, Sask.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not, or you say how old you were in years, etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming to Western Canada?

At the immigration offices at Winnipeg, they knew I was wanted off Metis Bank. I was driving the train that went, and there was a reward for me.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people's stories, reading about it, hearing from friends, or government information).

Government of Canada's exhibition work and radio talk in Canada, and then made a quick impression on me.

Worked on a farm for my Dad and did contracting for my Dad. Worked for wages after farming to Western Canada.

23. In there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

At that time the country was at ranching country, and all the country was open range or sheep, like me big family.

If you were riding by anyone's help behind meal-tops, land there was no one home, you could help yourself to everything there you could help yourself and be welcome.

I traveled about on Sunday mostly for pleasure. The nearest church I went three times. It was about twenty miles to Maple Creek and we traveled by mule horse.
